results.notes: Under oaks (road side) in a mixed forest with oaks and pines, shadow place. Pores cream to pale yellow. Flesh pale yellow, unchanging, on cap (after all it blued the next day). Pores and tubes blueing, but not the flesh of the cap. Flesh on stipe bright yellow, blueing when exposed to air. Similar to X.ferrugineus, X.submentosus and X.chrysonemus, except on the blueing feature. Smell not distinctive.

results.notes: Whitish cap, up to 78 mm. in diameter and 10 mm. thick above stipe, brownish warts. Crowded cream colored gills. Stipe is whitish, up to 105 mm. × 18 mm. excluding the bulb and covered in brownish floccose material. The annulus is skirt-like, cream color with brown remnants of universal veil on the underside. The bulb is 65 mm. long x 40 mm. wide. and covered with brown warts. On mossy ground under beech and balsam fir in mixed woods.

results.notes:
Large polypore that was mostly white, smooth, with a bit of a peach coloring on top, and yellow on the pore surface.

When I broke off a piece I saw a bit a of clear yellow fluid on the white inner flesh. Specimen was found around mostly broadleaf trees on a log in quite a cluster.

No apparent bruising at first.. but didn’t take a sample home to really check. The odor was quite fungal. Kinda appetizing.

The flesh felt a bit spongey, not too tough, and rather dry.

No bruising. FB’s dry and possibly faded as a result. On mossy ground in mixed woods that include beech, birch and balsam fir.
results.location_name: Perry, Maine, USA

results.notes:
Cap 38 mm., brown, convex, dry, felty, flesh thick and pale yellow. Pores pale yellow, small. Tubes yellow, depressed at stem. Stem pale yellow, 70 mm. × 15-30 mm., solid, tapered at apex, swollen at base, flesh pale yellow. All parts of FB bruising slowly mildly blue when cut or rubbed except cap surface which bruises darker brown and lower half of stem flesh which bruises red brown. No odor, mild taste. Cap surface orange with ammonia and red orange with KOH. On ground in mixed woods. Found a number of these over a few days, many were pretty far gone and quite large—stem bases fused in most.

Note: This is pretty clearly B. huronensis, see: http://www.fungikingdom.net/...

results.notes:
Small summer fruiting of white chanterelle- beneath Evergreen huckleberry, salal, Oregon grape(as we usually find them) with Douglas fir, Western red cedar and Western hemlock trees above.

Yellow staining where handled.

We used to sell lbs. of these when living in the Olympia, WA area West of the Cascades to local restaurants- this is the first time I have encountered them in a montane habitat. However, the symbiotic indicator plants are all identical- mainly Evergreen huckleberry and Oregon grape.

results.notes:
Code: Bot_621/2012/DSC_3677

Habitat: Light mixed wood, among bushes, almost flat terrain, half-shade, dry place, probably limestone bedrock, exposed to direct rain, average precipitations 1.200-1.300 mm/year, average temperature 12-14 deg C, elevation 360 m (1.100 feet), submediterranean phytogeographical region.

Substratum: soil.

Place: East of village Popetre, next to the road toward village Sveti Anton and town Koper, Primorska, Slovenia EC

Comment: This is another mycoheterotrophic orchid which is associated primarily with genus Russula. But the plant is not completely without chlorophyll. Despite the presence of photosynthetic pigments, CO2 fixation seems to be insufficient to compensate for respiration in adult plants (Ref.:(2)). Therefore fungal symbionts are needed to survive. Interestingly, seedlings develop very slowly, spending up to ten years underground before flowering. Growing in a group of a few plants. This plant is not common in Slovenia, however, also not a very rare one. It has very short time of flowering, which makes it difficult to find flowers ‘in a good shape’ for photography. Protected according to ‘Uredba o zavarovanih prosto živečih rastlinskih vrstah’ Ur.l. RS, št. 46/2004. Enlisted in the Slovene Red List of rare and endangered species, marked by “V” representing a vulnerable species.

Nikon D700 / Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8
results.location_name: Istra peninsula region, Primorska, Slovenia

Habitat: In old Picea abies forest, near forest edge, moderately south inclined mountain slope, locally almost flat terrain, calcareous ground, relatively humid and warm place, in shade, partly protected from direct rain, average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 2 – 4 deg C, elevation 1.330 m (4.350 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: soil, among roots and fallen rotten branches.

Place: Mount Mangart region, northwest of Mangartska planina pasture, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC

Comments: Growing in large groups in lines and arches, several tens of fruitbodies, pileus diameter up to 10(13) cm, slightly sticky when wet or on old fruitbodies, otherwise dry; stipe up to 8(9) cm high; SP rusty red brown (oac687). Traits fits well to Ref.:(2). Since it completely lacked violet/blue tint it seems to be C.g.var. acyaneus. This name is legitimate according to the MycoBank and listed in Slovenian checklist of fungi. It’s only listed in the Index Fungorum. KOH test hasn’t been done.

results.notes:
This is the same mystery bolete that was found in a different area of FPP last July (Obs. 102459). This time, it was mature enough to drop spores.

The spore print looks grayish-green rather than brown under natural light.

The spores are smooth but appear (1000x, mounted in 5% KOH) like the are “stuffed with broken glass”. I don’t know if it’s an optical illusion for I don’t have any filters installed.

Obtaining an ITS sequence met with failure due to the presence of multiple hybridized regions.

Comments from Linas Kudzma:
“I Spores are typically bolete-like and non-staining in Melzer’s. The hymenium crush mount has the usual basidia, etc, but also reveals long cells whose contents stain orange in Melzer’s, but are hyaline in a 20% Glycerol mount. Very interestingly, in 20% glycerol there are groups of distinctly reddish cells in among the normal hyaline basidia and other cells. This must be the red speckling of the pore surface. I did not even notice these red cells in the Melzer’s mount because they must not have stood out as much.”
results.location_name: Franklin Parker Preserve, Woodland Twp., New Jersey, USA

results.notes:
To begin with I am a total novice at wild mushrooms, mine always come from the store.

These unknown orange mushrooms magically appeared in my neighbors yard. Two days ago there was on small bright orange spot and today there is are 2 small patches ( 2×2 feet and one about 4×4 feet.

The ground is level, no trees close by and no dead wood close by. There was until a few years ago 3 large oak trees that grew about 10 feet away from where there are located. There is a birch tree approximately 12 feet away and a pine to the opposite direction roughly 16 feet away from the mushroom patch.

The smell of them are wonderful, very strong and earthy.

Any help in identifying these would be appreciated.
results.location_name: Glenmoor, East Liverpool, Ohio, USA

results.notes: Collected on hot day after almost 2 weeks without rain. Photos taken a few hours after collection so colors have changed somewhat. The cap had a more lilac gray to gray brown cast when I first spotted it in the woods. Cap up to 45 mm., dry, shiny, smooth, hairy at margin, gray white flesh. Gills cinnamon, broad, whitish partial veil. Stem 75 mm. × 12-22 mm., swollen at base, flesh lilac gray at top to gray white below. Pleasant taste. Distinctive odor, not pleasant. KOH on flesh of cap and stem purple brown.

results.notes: Cap, 25-50mm, reddish-orange with appressed redish fibrils, narrowly to broadly convex. Margin incurved to decurved. Whitish cortina became orange-brown, and leaving an evanescent zone of fibers near the apex. Stipe solid, clavate, whitish with with 1-3 reddish bands along its length. Cap context whitish; stipe context becoming light tanish near the base. Stipe 8-11mm at apex; 5-9cm long. Base has white rhizoides. Found among Betula alleghaniensis, Tsuga canadensis, and Acer.

I should have checked my photos before I delete4d them from my card.

results.notes:
These two Amanita-like muchrooms were very slimy-viscid on the cap. The color was a very pale tan with it becoming palet toward the mildly striate marin. Each specimen was approximately two-three inches in height and 2-2 1/2 inches in cap width. The gills were relatively fleshy with an irregular edge. No ring was visible on the white stipe. The base was very rounded and soft.
They were found under Eastern Whte pines in moss and pine needle debris.

Rod, if you are interested in looking at them, I have saved them.

results.notes:
An unusually-colored Validae species — the cap is gray with just a touch of a brownish hue. The cap margin appears to be non-striate (pix). The partial veil is very fragile, but remnants of it can still be seen clinging to the stipe. That, together with a small bulb, makes placement into the above section a certainty. The closest “match” is A. sp-54, but that one has a yellow volva and striate cap margins.

This material is in the hands of R.E.T.

results.notes:
Two basidicarps growing next to each other under blueberry bushes, pitch pines and young scrub oak.

Dimensions: Cap = ~6cm in diameter; stipe = 6 cm long

The cap is medium dingy yellow.

The pore surface is brownish. Pores are 2-3 per mm, not radially arranged.

The stipe is pale yellow overall, brighter yellow at the apex, covered with purplish or red-brown glandular dots. There is no annulus. Some purplish tones are visible near the base; the lower half has some lemon-yellow discoloration that darken brown over time.

Chemical Tests: KOH = pinkish orange on cap; flashing cherry-red then quickly transitioning to dark red-brown on flesh. NH4OH = pale olive green on cap; flashing blue-green then quickly turning deep olive green on the flesh.

Spore deposit: ochraceous-brown (not en masse)
